awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Free Boundary and Evolution Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Free boundary problems arise in many models in physics, engineering, fluid dynamics, and economics. Free boundaries correspond to sharp changes in the variables describing the problem. While significant progress has been made in the study of free boundary problems, many important questions have yet to be studied in the case of nonlinear partial differential equations and especially equations of mixed type. For these cases, a better understanding of properties of free boundaries, such as stability, regularity and geometric structure, would make it possible to study complex phenomena in real-world applications. The primary focus of this project is the study of shock reflection problems in gas dynamics, one of the most fundamental multidimensional shock wave problems. The project will also have a broad impact through close interactions with engineering and meteorological communities and through training of graduate students.

The project consists of two main topics: (1) Free boundary problems in shock analysis. The PI will continue his work on self-similar shock reflection for potential flow and for full and isentropic Euler system. Shock reflection problems arise in many physical situations. Moreover, such problems are important in the mathematical theory of multidimensional conservation laws since their solutions are building blocks and asymptotic attractors of general solutions to the multidimensional Euler equations for compressible fluids. Self-similar equations of compressible fluid dynamics are of mixed elliptic-hyperbolic type. Shocks correspond to discontinuities in the solution for Euler system, and in the gradient of the solution for potential flow equation. Type of equation may change from hyperbolic to elliptic across the shock. Shock reflection problem can be formulated as a free boundary problem in which unknown are the elliptic (subsonic) region and solution in the elliptic region. The PI will continue his work on existence, stability and regularity of global solutions of the regular reflection, to extend the global existence results to the case of compressible Euler system, which is a fundamental model of gas dynamics.  Further study includes uniqueness and stability for regular reflection problem in various classes of solutions. (2) Another area of the proposed research is semi-geostrophic system.  The PI will study semi-geostrophic system with variable Coriolis parameter. Such model arises from  taking into account the curvature of the Earth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. In the project the PI studied free boundary problems  for nonlinear partial differential equations arising in gas dynamics, and variational evolution problems modelling atmospheric flows.

 First area of the proposal is the study of free boundary problems in shock analysis. The PI continued work on self-similar shock reflection for potential flow model. Shock reflection problems arise in many physical situations. Moreover, such problems are important in the mathematical theory of multidimensional conservation laws since their solutions are building  blocks and asymptotic attractors of general solutions to the multidimensional Euler equations for compressible fluids. Self-similar equations of compressible fluid dynamics are of mixed elliptic-hyperbolic type. Shocks correspond to discontinuities in the gradient of the solution  (the velocity potential)  for potential flow equation. Type of equation may  change from hyperbolic to elliptic across the shock. Shock reflection  problem can be formulated as a free boundary problem in which unknowns are the elliptic (subsonic) domain and the solution in the elliptic domain,  where shock is the free boundary and the Rankine-Hugoniot conditions are satisfied on the shock. In the previous works, the PI  and his collaborator G.-Q. Chen (Oxford) completed  the proof of existence existence of global solutions of the regular reflection structure up in the maximal interval of physical parameters where such configuration is possible, thus completing the proof of von Neumann Detachment Conjecture, stated in 1940's, in the framework of the potential flow model. In this project, the PI and collaborators studied further properties of shock reflection solutions. They proved convexity of the shock (the free boundary). This result, in addition to its own interest, was then used to prove uniqueness and stability of regular reflection solutions, which is a fundamental peoperty, especially in the light of many recent results on non-uniqueness of solutions woth shocks. The PI and collaborators also obtained existence, convexity of shock, and uniqueness results for self-similar another shock reflection problem, the Prandtl reflection. This answers a long-standing question on physical significance of weak reflections versus strong reflection for steady shocks.

Another area of research was semigeostrophic system, a model of large-scale atmosphere/ocean flows, where 'large-scale' means that the flow is rotation-dominated. For the case of constant rotation rate, main tools in study semigeostrophic problem are base on Monge-Kantorovich mass transport theory. In previous works, the PI and collaborators proved existence of global in time appropriately weak solutions for general initial data. In the present project, the PI and collaborators worked on stability of solutions, and in particular proved weak-strong uniqueness. Another related work is to show that solutions of semigeostropfic sysem can be obtained as a limit of solutions of Euler system under the appropriate parameter limit, thus justifying rigorously the semigeostrophic model. The PI an collaborators obtained results in this direction.

Broader impact. The project addresses problems important in engineering and atmospheric sciences. Closer interaction withengineering and meteorological communities was one of the priorities of the project. In particular, the work on the semigeostrophic system have been carried out in collaboration with meteorologist Michael Cullen (Met Office, UK), which helped to broaden dissemination of the results among the atmospheric science community. Also, graduate students and postdoc of the PI have been involved in the work on the project.
